case_name: Secretary, Peoples Publishing House Ltd. v. Bombay Government

facts.text: Appeal under Article 132(1) of the Constitution from judgment and order dated 12th April 1950 of Bombay High Court by Chagla J, Bavdekar and Shah JJ, Case No. IX of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: APPELLATE JURISDICTION Appeal under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution from a judgment and order dated 12th April, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay  Chagla J., Bavdekar and Shah JJ.  Case No. I X of 1950.

facts.text: Petitioner was Secretary of Peoples Publishing House Ltd, incorporated under Indian Companies Act, registered office at 190-B Khetwadi Main Road Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: DAs J.--At all material times the petitioner, who is the appellant before us, was the Secretary of Peoples Publish- ing House, Ltd., a companypany incorporated under the Indian Companies Act with its registered office at 190-B, Khetwadi Main Road in Bombay.

facts.text: In September 1949, pamphlet entitled Railway Mazdooron ke khilaf Nai Zazish published in Bombay by petitioner as secretary of Peoples Publishing House Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: In September, 1949, a pamphlet entitled Railway Mazdooron ke khilaf Nai Zazish is alleged to have been published in Bombay by the petitioner as the secretary of that companypany.

facts.text: Counsel for petitioner states pamphlet was published as book under section 1 Press and Registration of Books Act XXV of 1867 and provisions complied with.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the peti- tioner states that the pamphlet was published as a book within the meaning of section 1 of the Press and Registra- tion of Books Act  XXV of 1867  and that the provisions of that Act had been duly companyplied with.

facts.text: Bombay Government authorities viewed pamphlet as news sheet under section 2(6) Indian Press Emergency Powers Act 1931, published without authority under section 15(1), offence under section 18(1).

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Government authorities, however, took the view that the pamphlet was a news sheet within the meaning of section 2  6  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act, 1931, and that as it had been published without the authori- ty required by section 15  1  of that Act, the petitioner had companymitted an offence punishable under section 18  1  of the same Act.

facts.text: Prosecution under Press Emergency Powers Act 1931 started against petitioner in Court of Chief Presidency Magistrate Bombay, registered as Case No. 1102/P of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: A prosecution under that Act was accordingly started against the petitioner in the Court of the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay, and was registered as Case No. 1102/P of 1949.

facts.text: Constitution of India came into force on January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the proceedings the Constitution of India came into force on January 26, 1950.

facts.text: On March 3, 1950, petitioner filed written statement claiming section 2(6), 15, 18 of Press Emergency Powers Act 1931 ultra vires article 19(1)(a) read with article 13, requested stay.

anchor.surface_text: On March 3, 1950, the petitioner filed a written statement submitting, inter alia, that the definition of news sheet as given in section 2  6  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act, 1931, and sections 15 and 18 thereof were ultra vires and void in view of article 19 1  a  read with article 13 and that the hearing of the case should be stayed till the High Court decided that question of law.

facts.text: On March 7, 1950, petitioner filed petition in Bombay High Court under article 228 praying for record of Case No. 1102/P/1949, declaration sections 15,18 with 2(6),2(10) ultra vires art19(1)(a), acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed up by a petition filed in the High Court on March 7, 1950, under article 228 of the Constitution, praying that the record of Case No. 1102/P of 1949 be sent for, that it be declared that sections 15 and 18 read with section 2  6  and  10 , in so far as they create liability for restrictive measure for a citizen, are ultra vires of article 19  1   a and are, therefore, void and inoperative and that the petitioner be ordered to be acquitted.

facts.text: On March 23, 1950, Chief Presidency Magistrate framed charge against petitioner under section 18 Press Emergency Powers Act 1931.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of this petition the Chief Presidency Magis- trate on March 23, 1950, framed a charge against the peti- tioner under section 18 of the Press  Emergency Powers  Act, 1931.

facts.text: On April 12, 1950, Bench of Bombay High Court consisting of Chagla CJ, Bavdekar and Shah JJ heard petition under art228, dismissed it holding pending proceedings not affected by art13(1).

anchor.surface_text: The petition under article 228 was heard on April 12, 1950, by a Bench of the Bombay High Court companysisting of Chagla C.J. and Bavdekar and Shah JJ. ... The High Court accordingly answered the second question in the af- firmative and dismissed the petitioners application.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under article 132(1) for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has number companye up on appeal before us on the strength of a certificate granted by the High Court under article 132 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Hearing in Supreme Court on Jan 22, 1951, judgment by Das J for Kania CJ, Patanjali Sastri J, Das J, Chandrasekhara Aiyar J; separate by Mahajan J, Fazl Ali J; Mukherjea J agreed with Fazl Ali J.

anchor.surface_text: 1951. Jan. 22. The judgment of Kania C.J., Patanjali Sastri J. Das J. and Chandrasekhara Aiyar J. was delivered by Das J. Mahajan J. and Fazl Ali J. delivered separate judgments. Mukherjea J. agreed with Fazl Ali J.

facts.text: Appellant arrested on 9th December 1949, prosecution started under s18(1) Indian Press Emergency Powers Act 1931 for publishing pamphlet Railway Mazdoorun Ke Khilaf Nai Sazish without authority u/s15(1).

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th December, 1949, the appel- lant was arrested and a prosecution was started against him under section 18 1  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act  XXIII of 1931  in the Court of the Chief Presidency Magistrate at Bombay for publishing a pamphlet in Urdu entitled Railway Mazdoorun Ke Khilaf Nai Sazish.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal, agreed with High Court that pending proceedings under Press Act not affected by art13(1).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, this appeal fails, and is dismissed.

facts.text: On 8th March 1950, application made in Bombay High Court under art228 to quash proceedings, claiming ss16,18 ultra vires Part III Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: On the 8th March, 1950, an application was made on his behalf in the High Court of Judicature at Bombay under article 228 of the Constitution of India for quashing the proceedings started against him.

arguments.claim: The pamphlet was published as a book within the meaning of section 1 of the Press and Registration of Books Act XXV of 1867 and that the provisions of that Act had been duly complied with.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the peti- tioner states that the pamphlet was published as a book within the meaning of section 1 of the Press and Registra- tion of Books Act  XXV of 1867  and that the provisions of that Act had been duly complied with.

arguments.claim: The pamphlet was a news sheet within the meaning of section 2(6) of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931, published without the authority required by section 15(1), committing an offence punishable under section 18(1).

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Government authorities, however, took the view that the pamphlet was a news sheet within the meaning of section 2  6  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act, 1931, and that as it had been published without the authori- ty required by section 15  1  of that Act, the petitioner had committed an offence punishable under section 18  1  of the same Act.

arguments.claim: Sections 2(6), 15 and 18 of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931 were ultra vires and void in view of article 19(1)(a) read with article 13.

anchor.surface_text: On March 3, 1950, the petitioner filed a written statement submitting, inter alia, that the definition of news sheet as given in section 2  6  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act, 1931, and sections 15 and 18 thereof were ultra vires and void in view of article 19 1  a  read with article 13 and that the hearing of the case should be stayed till the High Court decided that question of law.

arguments.claim: Sections 15 and 18 read with sections 2(6) and 2(10) of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931, in so far as they create liability for restrictive measure for a citizen, are ultra vires of article 19(1)(a) and void and inoperative; acquit petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed up by a petition filed in the High Court on March 7, 1950, under article 228 of the Constitution, praying that the record of Case No. 1102/P of 1949 be sent for, that it be declared that sections 15 and 18 read with section 2  6  and  10 , in so far as they create liability for restrictive measure for a citizen, are ultra vires of article 19  1   a and are, therefore, void and inoperative and that the petitioner be ordered to be acquitted.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court considered it unnecessary to decide

arguments.claim: Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931 is repressive alien law; article 13(1) declares inconsistent laws void as if never existed; pending prosecutions under such void law must fall to the ground after January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel appearing in support of this appeal urged that the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act, 1931, was one of the many repressive laws enacted by an alien Government with a view to stifle the liberty of the Indian subjects and particularly of the Indian Press that, with the advent of independence the people of India began to breathe freely and by the Constitution which they gave unto themselves they took care to guarantee to themselves the fundamental rights of free citizens of a democratic republic and that article 13  1  of that Constitution brushed aside all vestiges of subordination which the tyranny of the alien rulers had imposed upon them and declared all laws inconsistent with the fundamental rights to be void as if they had never been passed and had never existed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: existing laws with those rights must necessarily arise on and from the date those rights came into being. It must follow, therefore, that article 13

arguments.court_reasoning: Spirit argument attractive but court must follow language of Constitution; preservation of pending proceedings not foreign to Constitution.

arguments.claim: Void laws cannot be utilised after January 26, 1950 for framing charge or punishing; pending prosecutions fall as prolonging efficacy of void law against spirit of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel urged that it was not necessary for him to contend that such inconsistent laws became void ab initio or that all past and closed transactions could be reopened but he contended that on and from January 26, 1950, when the Constitution came into force such inconsistent laws which became void could not be looked at for any purpose and far less could they be utilised for the purpose of framing a charge or punishing a free citizen. As the void law cannot be utilised any longer, the pending prosecutions, according to learned counsel, must fall to the ground.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 3 , 250, 357, 358 and 369 where express provision has been made for saving things done under the laws which expired. It will be number ticed that each

arguments.court_reasoning: Article 13(1) prospective; past liabilities and pending proceedings survive.

arguments.claim: Word 'void' in article 13(1) used in sense of repealed, attracting section 6 of General Clauses Act via article 367; pending proceedings under Press Act not affected.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court took the view that the word void was used in article 13  1  in the sense of repealed and that consequently it attracted section 6 of the General Clauses Act, which Act by article 367 was made applicable for the interpretation of the Constitution. The High Court, therefore, reached the conclusion that proceedings under the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act, 1931, which were pending at the date of the commencement of the Constitution were not affected...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: h January, 1950, except that numbereffect can be given to any of its provisions which are repugnant to the fundamental rights guaranteed by the Consti

arguments.court_reasoning: Agree with conclusion on different grounds: prospective operation of Art 13(1).

arguments.claim: Article 13(1) is prima facie prospective; no retrospective operation; fundamental rights operative from commencement of Constitution; inconsistency arises only then; void only for future exercise of rights; pending proceedings and past liabilities unaffected.

anchor.surface_text: Every statute is prima facie pro- spective unless it is expressly or by necessary implications made to have retrospective operation. There is nothing in the language of article 13  1  which may be read as indicating an intention to give it retrospective operation. On the con- trary, the language clearly points the other way. ... It must follow, therefore, that article 13 1  can have no retrospective effect but is wholly pro- spective in its operation.

arguments.claim: Article 13(1) does not obliterate inconsistent laws entirely or ab initio; void only to extent of inconsistency with future exercise of fundamental rights; past transactions and accrued rights/liabilities remain.

anchor.surface_text: After this first point is disposed, it should further be seen that article 13  1  does not in terms make the existing laws which are inconsistent with the fundamental rights void ab initio or for all purposes. On the contrary, it provides that all existing laws, in so far as they are inconsistent with the fundamental rights, shall be void to the extent of their inconsistency.

arguments.claim: No necessity for saving clause in Art 13(1) unlike temporary statutes expiry, as Art 13(1) prospective; distinguishes effect of expiry/repeal.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant has drawn our attention to articles 249  3 , 250, 357, 358 and 369 where express provision has been made for saving things done under the laws which expired. ... The effect of article 13  1  is quite different from the effect of the expiry of a temporary statute or the repeal of a statute by a subsequent statute.

arguments.claim: 'Void' under Art 13(1) renders law ineffectual only prospectively for fundamental rights exercise; no retrospective wipe out; pending prosecutions proceed.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, agree with the conclusion arrived at by the High Court on the second question, although on different grounds. In view of that conclusion, we do not consider it necessary to examine the reasons of the High Court for its conclusion.

arguments.claim: Article 13(1) 'void' strongest expression, null and ineffectual; not repeal (used elsewhere); no saving clause; pending proceedings terminate like pre-Interpretation Act repeal or temporary expiry.

anchor.surface_text: I regret that I cannot agree with the view which the majority... From the earlier proceedings before the Constituent Assembly... the words shall stand abrogated were used... replaced by shall be void... treating an Act as void under article 13  1  should have a milder effect upon transactions not past and closed than the repeal of an Act or its expiry...

arguments.court_reasoning: Majority holds prospective operation preserves pending.

arguments.claim: Effect of repeal/expiry pre-saving statutes: pending proceedings ipso facto terminate; cites Craies, cases; applies analogously to void under Art 13(1).

anchor.surface_text: One of the points discussed... In Craies on Statute Law... offences committed against temporary Acts must be prosecuted... before the Act expires... Crawford... repeal divests inchoate rights, destroys pending proceedings without saving.

arguments.court_reasoning: Art 13(1) not repeal or expiry; prospective.

arguments.claim: Section 6 General Clauses Act applies only to express repeal, not implied voidness; principle not extendable; pending cannot proceed under ineffectual law.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General had to concede that it was doubtful whether section 6... is applicable where there is a repeal by implication... situations similar... have not been provided for.

arguments.claim: Proceedings under s18 Press Act before Constitution commencement not affected; no fundamental rights pre-Constitution; offence complete then; penalties survive; Art13(1) prospective only.

anchor.surface_text: The sole point to decide... whether proceedings instituted under section 18  1  ... before the commencement of the Constitution of India are affected by its provisions. The High Court has answered this question in the negative and, in my opinion, rightly.

arguments.claim: Art13(1) not analogous to repeal; void wipes statute from Jan26; dead statute, no charge/conviction possible; foreign repressive laws should not taint freedoms.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chari contended that the High Court was in error in applying... the power given was larger... wipe out the statute altogether from the date... under a dead statute no action could be taken whatsoever.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ompanyntry, in preference to the rule evolved by the English Judges in the earlier part of English legal history. Be that as it may, it is unnecessary

arguments.court_reasoning: Prospective; no retro effect on pending.

arguments.claim: 'Void' not ab initio or obliterating like old repeal rule; statutes prospective; no need saving as no retro; distinguishes American unconstitutional statutes.
Spirit argument (continue foreign sedition prosecutions repugnant) appeals to heart not head; relief by govt/legislature, not courts via retro construction.

holdings.text: Article 13(1) of the Constitution has no retrospective effect and is wholly prospective in its operation.

anchor.surface_text: Every statute is prima facie pro- spective unless it is expressly or by necessary implications made to have retrospective operation. There is nothing in the language of article 13  1  which may be read as indicating an

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutes are prima facie prospective; language of Art 13(1) shows no retrospective intent; fundamental rights commence with Constitution, so inconsistency arises prospectively.

holdings.text: Existing laws inconsistent with fundamental rights are void only to the extent of such inconsistency and only with respect to the future exercise of fundamental rights; they continue to apply to past transactions and pending proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: After this first point is disposed, it should further be seen that article 13  1  does not in terms make the existing laws which are inconsistent with the fundamental rights void ab initio or for all purposes. On the contrary, it provides that all existing laws, in so far as they are inconsistent with the fundamental rights, shall be void to the extent of their inconsistency.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 13(1) limits voidness to post-commencement exercise of rights; past liabilities and inchoate rights survive to avoid retrospective effect.

holdings.text: Pending proceedings instituted before the commencement of the Constitution under section 18(1) of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931, are not affected by Article 13(1), even assuming inconsistency with Article 19(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, agree with the conclusion arrived at by the High Court on the second question, although on different grounds. In view of that conclusion, we do not consider it necessary to examine the reasons of the High Court for its conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreeing with High Court conclusion via prospective operation of Art 13(1); no need to decide inconsistency as proceedings survive.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to decide whether sections 15(1) and 18(1) read with sections 2(6) and 2(10) of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931, are inconsistent with Article 19(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court considered it unnecessary to deal with or decide the first question and disposed of the application only on the second question... We, therefore, agree with the conclusion arrived at by the High Court on the second question... In view of that conclusion, we do not consider it necessary to examine the reasons of the High Court for its conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resolution of second issue suffices for disposal; assumption of inconsistency for argument.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, this appeal fails, and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pending proceedings unaffected by Art 13(1); High Court order upheld.

anchor.surface_text: When an Act of Parliament is repealed, said Lord Tenterden in Surtees v. Ellison 2  it must be 1947 F.C.R. 141 at 166.  2  1829 9 B C. 752. companysidered  except as to transactions past and closed  as if it had never existed.

precedents.cited_proposition: Repeal of Act means it is considered as if never existed except for past and closed transactions
precedents.cited_holding: When an Act of Parliament is repealed... except as to transactions past and closed as if it had never existed

anchor.surface_text: Tindal J. states the exception more widely. He says  in Kay v. Goodwin  1  ,, The effect of repealing a statute is to obliterate it as companypletely from the records of the Parlia- ment as if it had never been passed

precedents.cited_proposition: Effect of repealing a statute is to obliterate it completely as if never passed, except for commenced, prosecuted and concluded actions
precedents.cited_holding: The effect of repealing a statute is to obliterate it as completely... as if it had never been passed... except for the purpose of those actions which were commenced, prosecuted and concluded whilst it was an existing law

precedents.citation: Cleveland, etc., R. Co. v. Mumford Ind.

anchor.surface_text: See Cleveland, etc., R. Co. v. Mumford Ind.   2  where the repeal of a statute during the trial prevented a judg- ment from being rendered. Similarly, there can be numberlegal

precedents.cited_proposition: Repeal of statute during trial prevents judgment from being rendered

precedents.citation: Wall v. Chesapeake Ohio Ry., Company

anchor.surface_text: quote the following passage from Wall v. Chesapeake Ohio Ry., Company  1 -- It is well settled that if a statute giving a special remedy is repealed without a saving clause in favour of pending suits all suits must stop where the repeal finds them.

precedents.case_name: Wall v. Chesapeake & Ohio Railway Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: Repeal of statute without saving clause stops pending suits; obliterates statute as if never existed except for concluded actions
precedents.cited_holding: If a statute giving a special remedy is repealed without a saving clause... all suits must stop where the repeal finds them... Pending judicial proceedings based upon a statute cannot proceed after its repeal.

anchor.surface_text: In R. v. Mawgan Inhabitants  1  a presentment as to the number-repair of a highway had been made under 13 Geo. 3, c. 78, s. 24, but before the case came on to be tried, the Act was repealed.

precedents.cited_proposition: After repeal of Act, no further effect can be given to proceedings under it, though past acts not invalidated
precedents.cited_holding: If the question had related merely to the presentment... But... we have lost the power of giving effect to anything that takes place under that proceeding... what is already done has become bad, but that numbermore can be done.

anchor.surface_text: This rule seems to be based on a statement of Tindal C.J. in Kay v. Goodwin 1 . The learned Chief Justice made the following observations -- I take the effect of repealing a statute to be, to obliterate it as companypletely

precedents.cited_proposition: Repeal obliterates statute as if never passed, except for actions commenced, prosecuted and concluded while existing
precedents.cited_holding: I take the effect of repealing a statute to be, to obliterate it as completely from the records of Parliament as if it had never been passed and it must be considered as a law that never existed except for the purpose of those actions which were commenced, prosecuted and concluded whilst it was an existing law.

anchor.surface_text: After this first point is disposed, it should further be seen that article 13  1  does not in terms make the existing laws which are inconsistent with the fundamental rights void ab initio or for all purposes. On the contrary, it provides that all existing laws, in so far as they are inconsistent with the fundamental rights, shall be void to the extent of their inconsistency.
In our opinion, therefore, this appeal fails, and is dismissed.
